class_notes:
"Americas Queer: North and South" | How can "queerness" be understood in a pan-American framework? Do the Americas have a common "queerness"? And if not, what changes in terms of the definitions, practices, inflections are incidental to the term and which render the term into a constitutively different one? Can we talk on the one hand, about queerness as practice versus queerness as identity? 
The course moves in a general historical framework, as we examine different moments of what can perhaps be understood as a common history. The course starts in the 1880s, with Oscar Wilde's celebrity tour of the United States, at the height of his popularity when, as a member of the audience, the Cuban patriot and revolutionary Jose Marti wrote an account of what he saw that was reprinted all over Latin America. Other readings include: Feferico Garcia Lorca in New York, Hart Crane in Havana, Elizabeth Bishop in Brazil, William Burroughs in Mexico, etc.


Other authors / texts include: Gabriela Mistral, Manuel Puig, Gabriela Cabezon Camara, Nestor Perlomngher, Alejandra Pizarnik, Rita Indiana Hernandez, Yolanda Arroyo Pizarro, and others.


Films include: The Kiss of the Spider Woman, Do√±a Herlinda and her Son, Mala Mala, Brincando el Charco, and others.


Requirements: Three short papers (60%), Midterm, (15%), Oral presentation (10%) Written reactions, participation and attendance (15%)
course_description: An introduction to different methods of literary criticism and textual interpretation, applying a variety of theoretical approaches to selected literary texts.  Readings include essays, fiction, poetry, and drama. *Note: This course is non-repeatable.
